Award.AwardTitle: Understanding Horizontal Gene Transfer in Bacteria and Archaea: Units of Transfer and Modes of Integration

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most important, but poorly understood, drivers of microbial evolution is horizontal gene transfer (HGT), when whole genes or large gene fragments are passed along between two bacterial cells, sometimes representing different species. Understanding how HGT occurs may shed light on the adaptation of microbes to new ecological niches, evolution and spread of antibiotic resistance genes, the rise of emerging pathogens, and competition between microbes. The outcomes of the proposed research will include new computational methods and techniques for analyzing HGT events, open-source software tools for use by biologists, and valuable new insights into different types of HGT events in oceanic bacteria. The project will train three PhD students and at least three undergraduate students in interdisciplinary research skills. The project will also introduce several high-school students to bioinformatics research and provide training to several high-school science teachers on computational molecular evolution. Research results will also be integrated into graduate and undergraduate level classroom teaching.

The project focuses on two fundamental properties of HGTs. The first property deals with the 'mode' of an HGT event, which defines whether the transferred gene is 'additive' or 'replacing', i.e., whether it adds itself as a new gene to the recipient genome or replaces an existing homologous gene. The second property concerns the units of HGT events, i.e., whether the HGT event involved a gene fragment, entire gene, several genes, or entire operons. The project entails development of new, broadly applicable, computational methods to infer the modes and units of HGT events, application of these methods to microbial genome datasets to investigate the frequencies and roles of the different modes and units of HGT events in various evolutionary scenarios, and testing of specific hypotheses relating these properties of HGT events to evolutionary divergence, HGT integration mechanism, and gene function.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to improve our understanding of Horizontal Gene Transfer (HGT), a crucial evolutionary process in microbes. The project specifically focused on two fundamental properties of HGTs: modes and units. The mode of an HGT event defines whether the transferred gene is additive or replacing, i.e., whether it adds itself as a new gene to the recipient genome or replaces an existing homologous gene, and the unit of an HGT event defines whether that transfer involved a gene-fragment, a single complete gene, or multiple genes. A more complete understanding of HGT can shed light on many important biological questions, including those related to the adaptation of microbes to new ecological niches, coevolution of genes despite disruptions due to HGT, evolution and spread of antibiotic resistance genes, emerging pathogens, and competition between microbes.

To achieve the specific research goals of this project, we developed many new computational methods for inferring and analyzing HGTs, released several new open-source software packages, applied the new methods to large-scale genomic data to study the units and modes of HGTs, and tested specific biological hypotheses relating modes, units, evolutionary divergence, integration mechanisms, and function. Some of the significant computational/methodological innovations enabled by this project include (i) development of effective computational techniques for handling gene tree error and uncertainty to improve the accuracy of HGT inference, (ii) development of the first computational and statistical framework for large-scale inference of multi-gene HGTs, (iii) development of the first probabilistic simulation framework for simulating subgene level HGT, additive and replacing HGT,  and other important aspects of microbial gene family evolution, (iv) development of several new computational approaches, the first of their kind, for inferring and distinguishing between additive and replacing HGTs, and (v) development of a novel computational approach to identify possible subgene HGT in the evolutionary history of a gene family.

The research supported by this project has resulted in ten journal and peer-reviewed conference publications, and two manuscripts that are currently under review for journal publication. In addition, three manuscripts describing core research results are currently in preparation. The project also enabled the development of six freely available open-source software packages: RANGER-DTL v2.0 for phylogenetic reconciliation and HGT inference, TreeSolve for rapid gene tree error-correction, SaGePhy for probabilistic phylogenetic simulation of gene and subgene evolution, RF+ for phylogenetic tree comparison, HoMer for inference of multi-gene horizontal transfers, and ARTra for machine learning-based classification of HGTs as being additive or replacing. Two additional software packages developed as part of this project, one for classification of additive/replacing HGTs and another for detection of subgene HGT, will also be released shortly. All software packages are freely available from the PI’s lab website: https://compbio.engr.uconn.edu/software/

Many of the methods and software tools mentioned above are the first of their kind and make it possible to study those aspects of HGT in microbes that were either difficult or impossible to study previously. For instance, biological data analysis using these methods/tools has already revealed many novel insights into the prevalence and patterns of multi-gene HGT and into the functional biases, prevalence, and integration mechanisms of additive and replacing HGTs. The open-source and easy-to-use software packages developed through this project will allow any biologist or end user to easily apply the new methods to their own datasets.  

This project also provided invaluable interdisciplinary research experience to six graduate and six undergraduate students. Among the six graduate students, two were from biology and four (including two females) from computer science. Two of these students, one from biology and one from computer science graduated with their PhDs during this project and both started postdoctoral research positions at other institutions. Among the six undergraduate students, one was from biology and five (including one African-American female) from computer science. Three of these students are pursuing their PhDs in computer science at MIT, Stanford, and UConn, and a fourth student is currently applying for admission to PhD programs to begin in 2021. The project also facilitated the training of seventeen middle- and high-school science teachers (of which fourteen were female and five were African-American) from across the US as part of the intensive week-long workshop titled "Bioinformatics: Using computer science to understand life" taught by the PI in July 2016, 2017, 2018, and 2019. Participating teachers were trained in the basic principles and techniques of bioinformatics and were provided with simple bioinformatics exercises that they can use in their own classrooms.
